folders.name: Success Plan
folders.content:
Success Plan 


1. Background / Academic Challenges (History and Challenges)

I began studying computer science in earnest for the first time in college.

In my junior and senior high schools in Japan, programming education was limited to an introductory level, preventing me from gaining a systematic understanding. As a result, when I enrolled in an American university, the learning hurdles were high, especially in programming classes like C++.

I tried hard, using textbooks I brought from Japan, repeatedly reviewing materials, and self-studying, but it was difficult to adapt to a different academic culture and keep up with classes taught entirely in English.

In addition to these academic challenges, my physical and mental health getting significantly worse on two occasions. During these periods, I suffered from extreme stress, depression, persistent vomiting, headaches, and fatigue. These symptoms made it difficult for me to attend classes, communicate with others, and seek help in a right time. As a result, I missed classes for extended periods without proper notice, which led to my suspension and me earning zero credits for the two semesters.


2. Reflection and Responsibility

I take full responsibility for my poor academic performance and its consequences. My most serious mistake relates not only to my health issues, but also to my response to them. I did not proactively manage my physical and mental health and contact my professors, advisor, or university office. I also neglected to complete the necessary procedures for absence and withdrawal. After my academic work fell behind, I was overwhelmed with guilt and regret, and completely withdrew from communication.

I deeply regret the trouble my actions have caused my professors, advisor, and the university. I also regret breaking the promise I made after completing the Restart Program following my initial suspension. I now fully understand that my silence and habit of running away were the primary cause of my failure, not a lack of ability or motivation.


3. Improvement Actions Currently Implemented

After returning to Japan, I took specific steps to prevent these issues from recurring.

ãƒ»I consulted with several people in Japan about my mental health, academic stress, and future plans.

ãƒ»I took time to rest and mentally reset in a stable environment.

ãƒ»My father provided strong emotional support and actively helped me recover academically and get back into the rhythm of daily life.

ãƒ»I deeply reflected on my past behavior and recognized the importance of communicating and seeking help early.

These measures helped me regain mental stability and clarify my resolve to return to my studies with a more responsible and sustainable approach.





4. Health Management and Communication System

If I am allowed to return to university, I promise to take the following specific actions:

ãƒ»Prompt Communication

If I am feeling unwell or anticipate difficulty attending class, I will contact my instructor as soon as possible, or at the latest immediately after class, and clearly explain the reason.

ãƒ»Obligation to Report Long-Term Absences

If I require long term absences due to illness, I will proactively contact my academic advisor to discuss adjustments to my course load, temporary accommodations, and formal procedures.

ãƒ»No Isolation Policy

I hereby formally pledge not to cut off all contact with the university, faculty, or advisor under any circumstances.

ãƒ»Using Support Services

I will not attempt to cope with difficulties alone and will actively utilize advising and counseling resources.


5. Academic Strategy and Programming Preparation

To overcome my academic weaknesses, especially in programming, I have developed the following plan.

I will thoroughly review all C++ courses I have taken to date using the following materials:

- English textbooks used in class

- Japanese textbooks and reference books to strengthen my understanding

During my stay in Japan, I will devote the spring semester to systematic review and practice, with the goal of returning home fully prepared and confident by the summer semester.

I will also meet regularly with my academic advisor to monitor my progress.


6. Commitment to Success

I fully understand that this appeal represents a final opportunity.
If permitted to return early, I commit myself to academic integrity, consistent communication, responsible health management, and continuous self-improvement.

I am no longer seeking a chance simply to continue my studiesâ€”I am seeking the opportunity to prove that I have learned from my failures and can succeed under clear structure and accountability.

I respectfully ask the committee to consider my sincere reflection, the concrete changes outlined in this plan, and my strong determination to return as a responsible and successful student.
